bibl.title: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company template

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

body.div:
French Miners Strike: Delegates Meet Masters
LENS, March 17. M. Clemencean has arrived here. He ad-dressed the strikers and said that he respecter their right to strike and would send no troops as long as they remained orderly.
Owing to the danger of the decomposing bodies in the Conrrieres mines, it is expected that the aothorities will decide to wall up the galleries containing the victims, converting them into a vast necropolis. (Remter)
LENS, March 17. The strikers now number 32,0 0. M. Cle- mencean, Minister of the Interior, has visited the coalfields, and recommended calm. (H.)
PARIS, March 18. The Conrrieres miners and masters’ represen¬tatives have assembled here. The masters have conceded increases of wages which the men will consider. ( Router
PARIS, March 18. The delegates of the strikers at Pas-de Calais and the representatives of the mining companies met at the Ministry of Public Works. The companies agree to an increase of 10 per cent. The delegates will consult the strikers. (H.
<
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE. COMPLETE STANDSTILL
ALGECIRAS, March 18. The Conference is at a complete standstill. The Swiss aothorities are greatly annoyed at the Austro-German proposal to appoint a Swiss inspector without consulting the Federation. (Reuter)
CHINESE LABOUR. A CONTROVERSEY
LONDON, March 17. Mr. Winston Churchill, writing to a corres¬pondent, accuses Mr. Chamberlain of causing a depreciation in Kaffir securities by lugubrious and pessimistic orations.
Mr. Winston Churchill's speech in the House of Commons, and especially his threat of veto, has aroused indignation in South Africa. (Reuter)
LONDON, Maroh 18. Mr. Chamberlain, in a letter to the "Times,” in reply to Mr. Winston Churchill (mentioned on the 16th instant), accuses the Government of inconsistency regarding the Chinese and declares that any attempt to veto the Trans¬vaal Government's decision thereanent would probably lead to a serious conflict
EDUCATION BILL. NONCOMFORMISTS ALARMED
LONDON. March 17. The Non-conformits are alarmed by the rumours that the Government contemplate making concessions to Catholics in their new Education Bill, and threaten to renew the agitation in a most vigorous manner if this be true- (Revt*-)
TURKEY AND PERSIA
CONSTANTINOPLE March 17. The British and Russian Embassies are lend¬ing their good offices to secure an equitable settlement between Turkey and Persia, (FF.J)
BULGARIA BANDS AGAIN
A THINS, March 17. Bulgarian bands are commending their crimes of depredation again. They have set fire to a Greek village and killed several people. (Hanas)
TERRIBLE EARTHQUAKE IN JAPAN
Tokyo. March 18. A terrible earthquake has taken place at Kagi. Several hundred buildings have been destroyed and many hundreds of persons have been killed or injured. (Reuter
FLOODS IN BRAZIL
LONDON March 18. Over 50 men have been killed and many injured owing to landslides and floods in Brazil. (Renter
RUSSIA AND JAPAN
T. PETERSBURG, March 17. The report is denied that the Tear is sending a Grand Bake to Japan. (Feuter)
SEVASTOPOL MUTINY
ST. PETERSBURG Match 18 The sentence on Lieutenant Schmidt connected with the Sevastopol mutiny, has been commoted to being shot instead of being hanged. - Reuter
ST PATRICK'S DAY
LONDON, March 18 St. Patrick’s Day was celebrated with the commentary enthusiasm, and by concerts and parades of the Irish regiments. Shamrock was universally worn in London. {Kmttr
CENSUS OF GERMAN EMPIRE
BERLIN, Marrh 18. The census of the German Empire shows a population of 60,605,183. (Reuter),
INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL
London, March 17.
Association Scotland beat Ireland by one to
nil.
Rugby England beat Scotland by 9 to 8.
(Reuter)
OUR SPECIAL CABLES ALEGRECIAS CONFERENCE INTERNATIONAL GUAREANTEE DISCUSSED (GARETTE' SPECIAL SERVICE
LONDON, Monday. The “Echo de Paris” correspondent at Algeciras declares that the question of an international guarantee is at present being discussed in Paris, London, and Berlin by various members of the diplomatic corps. It is stated that a proposition has been forwarded by Italy in this connection. In the event of Germany acquiescing in this suggestion the •access of the conference is assured, otherwise failure is inevitable.
AMERICAN STOCKS AND SHARES
GERMANY AND THASOS
It has been an open secret fur some time that Germany has been actively at work in the direction of obtaining from Turkey the concession of a port which could be turned into a naval station and coaling station. The Constantinople correspondent of ‘ Le Petit Parisien” writes that Germany has made choice of the island of Thasos, in the extreme north of the Egean Sea. The island was given to the Khedive Ismail Pacha, and the present Khedive is now its owner. Although the Khedive has worked the greater part of the land and forests, he has granted certain concessions for exploiting the natural wealth of Thasos. The most important of these concessions is one which was obtained some years
GREECE AND EGYPT
The protocol of the commercial convention between Greece and Egypt has been drawn up and the usual exchange of signatures has taken place between the Minister of Foreign Affairs and M. Naoum, the delegate of the Greek Government. We understand that the difficulties that at one time impeded negotiations have been The protocol of the commercial convention between Greece and Egypt has been drawn up and the usual exchange of signatures has taken place between the Minister of Foreign Affairs and M. Naoum, the delegate of the Greek Government
MUNICIPAL COMMISSIONS
The Superior Council for the Municipally Commissions met on Saturday under the presidency of Ibrahim Pasha Neghib to con¬sider the budgets of the various Commissions for the current year.
THE SCHOOL STRIKES
The students of the School of Agriculture have returned on being informed by the director of the granting of an amnesty by the Minis¬ter of Pubic Instruction. At 8 a.m. on Saturday all appeared and there is every reason to expect that after their warning they will give no further trouble to the authorities. It is to be hoped that we have how heard the last of these school strikes.
THE RAILWAY CARDES
The question of the Cadres of the Egyptian Railway Administration will be finally dealt with by the Ministry of Finance in a few days' time.
SUEZ NAVAL NOTE (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
8uez, Saturday. The U. S. Army transports Kilpatrick and McClellan sailed from Suez this forenoon bound to Manila. The Coast-Guard cruiser Nour El Bahr has now entered the dry-hook here to be over hauled, and H. H. S. Aida is running des patches between Suez and Akaba temporarily.
H. M. transport Sicilia arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon from Bombay, and entered the Canal the same evening.
The Russian steamer Engineer Ardakoff entered the Canal yesterday evening bound for Alexandria with a full cargo of rice.
FASHIONABLE MARRIAGE. KNATCHBULL-PEEL
The marriage of Captain R. N. Knatobball. D.S.O., Leiorstershire Regiment, to Winifred, daughter of Mr. W. T. Peel, of The Bungalow, Fleming, and Hawley Hill, B'ackwater Hants, was solemnized at St. George’s Garrison Church, Mustapha, on Saturday, 17th inst. ,St. Patrick’s Day). The church was decorated for the occasion with palms and arum lilies and the service was fully choral, the music and choir being furnished by the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers by the kind permission of Col. Bird and the officers of the regiment. The bride groom was attended by Captain Gordon, Leicestershire Regiment. The bride arrived at 1.45, accompanied by her father. She wore a Liberty pictured gown of white satin, the corsage draped with Carrickmacross applique the gift of Miss Parsons. Her court train of white silk gauze, lined with chiffon, was carried by her niece and nephew, Miss Irene and Master Arthur Hogg, and she carried a bouquet of white roses and lilies of the valley and wore a sapphire and pearl pendant, the gifts of the bridegroom. Her four brides¬maids were Miss Grace Peel (sister), Miss Parsons, and the Misses Iris and Rhoda Rriss, nieces of the bride. Their dresses were white Oriental satin over mauve silk with mauve sashes and hats of tucked mauve silk trim¬med with tu le of a darker shade and pink roses. They carried bouquets of Dijon roses, the two elder bridesmaids wearing gold lockets with the bride’s miniature portrait and the younger ones silver muff-chains with charms, the gift of the bridegroom. The little page wore a suit of white satin with three-cornered The bride’s mother wore a Liberty gown of soft petunia satin with black hat trimmed with feathers and carried a bouquet of white roses. The hymn ‘O Perfect Love” was sung, kneel¬ing, at the commencement of the service, which was conducted by the Rev. F. Norman- Lee, chaplain to the forces, assisted by the Rev. Canon Ward, of St Mark’s, Alexandria. The bridal party left the church to the strains of Mendelssohn’s wedding march and proceed¬ed to the Bungalow, where Mrs. W F. Peel held a largely-attended reception.
Captain and Mrs. Knatchholl left during the afternoon for Cairo for a short honey¬moon and are leaving Suez to Colombo on the 12th April. The bride’s going-away dress was of silk and she wore a picture hat of brown - crinoline straw trimmed with large shaded brown ostrich feathers.
The presents which were very numerous and beautiful included the following as well as some, which, owingBridegroom to bride, sapphire . and pearl pendant, sapphire ring ; bride to bride¬groom, gold locket with miniature; cheque, fitted canteen, silver tea service, and card table, Mr. and Mrs. W. F. Peel ; Crown Derby dessert service. Col. andMrs. Norton Knatchbull ; revolving soap tureen, Col. and Mrs. Norton Knatchbull; diamond and emerald hoop, diamond and ruby hoop, Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Reis ; silver Bon-de-Cologne case, Miss Iris Reiss ; silver box-pi cushion. Miss Rhoda Reiss ; cheque, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg ; silver coffee pot.
